The Requirements Engineering Directive is applicable to all Information Technology (IT) and other stakeholders having responsibility for developing IT business processes.

Engineering Directive

) This document describes the formal Information Technology (IT) policy for implementing the requirements of the Requirements Engineering (RE) It provides the purpose, scope, authority, and mandates for institutionalizing this process. (

) Purpose - The purpose of this directive is to establish the Requirements neering Program Office’s (REPO) authority and responsibility for the execution, and oversight of the Requirements Development and Management process areas, hereafter referred to as RE. This directive expectations for REPO to support the establishment and advancement of RE discipline, and the expectations of all Programs and Projects that or maintain systems within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). (

) Audience - The Requirements Engineering Directive is applicable to all Infor- mation Technology (IT) organizations, contractors, and other stakeholders having responsibility for developing IT business processes. (
) Policy Owner - REPO under Business Planning and Risk Management (
) Program Owner - REPO is responsible for the development, implementation, and maintenance, of this directive. Approval of this directive, including rests with the REPO Office. (

) Primary Stakeholders - All Programs and Projects that develop or maintain systems are required to perform requirements engineering processes and sociated activities in accordance with this directive. (

) Program Goals - REPO is responsible for deﬁning, developing, updating, institutionalizing the RE discipline to facilitate program/project of quality requirements that accurately reﬂect the needs of the business and customers. The RE discipline includes, but is not limited to, requirements tation, deﬁnition, and management leveraging traditional and agile methods, lean principles, supported by model-based approaches, business rules, ization, and textual-based requirements. This directive, along with REPO training, guidance, coaching, material, and tools, supports all deﬁned Enter- prise Life Cycle (ELC) paths at the IRS. (

) Inefficiencies and gaps in program and project RE execution as recognized through external and internal process audits necessitated having established guidelines and principles that help minimize waste, training to disseminate knowledge, and coaching for individualized assistance and support. Further efficiency and waste reduction may be realized through an incremental and more agile development model promulgated by REPO. (

) The purpose of this directive is to establish the REPO authority and bility for the deﬁnition, execution, and oversight of the Requirements Development and Requirements Management process areas, hereafter referred to as RE. This directive clariﬁes expectations for REPO to support establishment and advancement of the RE discipline, and the expectations all Programs and Projects that develop or maintain systems within the IRS.
Engineering Directive 2.110.1

Purpose - The purpose of this directive is to establish the Requirements Engi- neering Program Office’s (REPO) authority and responsibility for the deﬁnition, execution, and oversight of the Requirements Development and Requirements Management process areas, hereafter referred to as RE. This directive expectations for REPO to support the establishment and advancement of the RE discipline, and the expectations of all Programs and Projects that develop or maintain systems within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).
Requirements (

) All Programs and Projects that develop or maintain systems are required to perform requirements engineering processes and associated activities in dance with this directive and are subject to REPO review and risk reporting to ensure compliance. The RE discipline includes, but is not limited to, require- ments elicitation, deﬁnition, and management leveraging traditional and agile methods, lean principles, supported by model-based approaches, business rules, visualization, and textual-based requirements. This directive, along with REPO training, guidance, coaching, material, and tools, supports all deﬁned ELC paths at the IRS. (
) REPO’s RE Authority and Responsibilities are further described in Paragraph
in the Organizational Directives. (

) REPO is responsible for the development, implementation, and maintenance, of this directive. Approval of this directive, including updates, rests with the REPO Office. All proposed changes to this directive must be submitted to REPO. (

) The following section is broken down into Organizational and Program/Project Directives. Organization Directives are those followed by REPO to deﬁne and institutionalize RE across the IRS. Program/Project Directives are those that must be followed by all Programs and Projects at the IRS. (

) Deﬁnition: REPO is responsible for deﬁning, developing, updating, and institu- tionalizing the RE discipline to facilitate program/project implementation of quality requirements that accurately reﬂect the needs of the business and its customers. REPO’s deﬁnition of the RE methodology supports all ELC paths, and is also inclusive of but not limited to waterfall and agile approaches. (

) Education and Training: REPO is responsible for making education and training available to personnel in overall RE methodology, supporting best practices, tailoring, RE methodology implementation as applicable to software development life cycles, and use of supporting requirements tools. (

) Mentoring and Coaching: REPO assists and partners with program and teams to effectively implement the RE discipline and raise the team’s RE skill level. REPO provides available support for the development and of requirements through all periods of system development, and for any opment approach the project may employ. The level of assistance is tailored criticality, scope of need, and resources. (

) Tools Management and Support: REPO supports projects by ensuring ments engineering methodology and standards are enforced by various Commercial Off the Shelf tools. These tools include but are not limited to: Rational DOORS Next Generation, Rational System Architect, Rational Team Concert, Rational Publishing Engine, Rational Reporting for Development ligence, and Justinmind. These tools aid projects with business solutions planning, analysis, business process modeling, operational concept develop- ment, business solution architecture, business rules and requirements development, visualization and simulations for requirements development, laboration among the development team, business, and stakeholders, management of lifecycle activities throughout development, project/program and organizational improvement, and strategic planning. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
A
2.110 Requirements Engineering

All Programs and Projects that develop or maintain systems are required to perform requirements engineering processes and associated activities in dance with this directive and are subject to REPO review and risk reporting to ensure compliance. The RE discipline includes, but is not limited to, require
ments elicitation, deﬁnition, and management leveraging traditional and agile methods, lean principles, supported by model
based approaches, business rules, visualization, and textual
based requirements. This directive, along with REPO training, guidance, coaching, material, and tools, supports all deﬁned ELC paths at the IRS.

Education and Training: REPO is responsible for making education and training available to personnel in overall RE methodology, supporting best practices, tailoring, RE methodology implementation as applicable to software development life cycles, and use of supporting requirements tools.
Engineering Directive 2.110.1
Engineering Directive

) Quality Assurance and Process Compliance, Including Review: REPO will assist Programs and Projects in assuring adherence of RE processes and products against REPO methodology and process guidance. REPO holds pliance approval authority of RE work products and artifacts identiﬁed in the ELC. At its discretion or by authorized REPO management request, REPO review selected system initiatives for RE quality and compliance with RE process and methodology guidance. Feedback will be provided by REPO aimed towards process improvement and subject to disposition by the Signiﬁcant ﬁndings will be communicated to the governing organization(s) may result in a project/program improvement action, and/or a Milestone Readiness Review Conditional Exit documented in the ELC Office Memo to Governance Committee and recorded as risks by the project. (

) Process Improvement: REPO will revise and extend the RE process, activities, roles, responsibilities, methods, tools, and templates. It will to improve education and training material, delivery and availability, and coaching and consulting services execution, based on feedback, lessons learned, and ongoing industry analysis. REPO will work with all process owners to further improve the Software Development Life Cycle. (

) To ensure compliance to REPO guidance, all Programs and Projects shall the following: • Follow the ELC: In accordance with the selected ELC path, complete requirements activities, ELC deliverables, and submit appropriate Item Descriptions to REPO for approval. • Training: Prior to conducting RE activities, ensure training is received personnel on the objectives, guidance, principles, and engineering proaches for performing RE activities, and proper use and RE Tools according to REPO deﬁned methodologies. • Scope: Deﬁne, analyze, and document scope and requirements models, rules, visualization, user stories, and statements in a way maximizes understandability, completeness, maintainability, and with REPO guidance. • Tool Usage: Manage all requirements, collaborative life cycle ment functions, and trace relationships using a REPO supported tool conjunction with a REPO deﬁned template and usage model. • Release Allocation: Prioritize requirement artifacts and allocate them against releases, sprints, and development increments. • Monitor RE Execution: Monitor execution of the RE process against plans that deﬁne and control development activities and take ate corrective action when necessary. This includes responding to all feedback from REPO reviews. • Analyze Requirements: Utilize modeling, rules, visualization, and REPO supported techniques to elaborate and decompose to a level that can be understood by the business and built against the development team. Reusable Program Level Requirements must assessed to ensure that Section
, Security, Privacy, Operational, Custodial Financial, IPv

, etc., are incorporated into the system and development. • Visualization: Programs, projects, or releases with a user interface leverage visualization to specify user interface requirements, screen ﬂow, and design. The visualization supports detailed user interface quirements.

coaching and consulting services execution, based on feedback, lessons learned, and ongoing industry analysis. REPO will work with all process owners to further improve the Software Development Life Cycle. To ensure compliance to REPO guidance, all Programs and Projects shall do the following: • Follow the ELC: In accordance with the selected ELC path, complete requirements activities, ELC deliverables, and submit appropriate Item Descriptions to REPO for approval. • Training: Prior to conducting RE activities, ensure training is received personnel on the objectives, guidance, principles, and engineering ap- proaches for performing RE activities, and proper use and application RE Tools according to REPO deﬁned methodologies. • Scope: Deﬁne, analyze, and document scope and requirements using models, rules, visualization, user stories, and statements in a way that maximizes understandability, completeness, maintainability, and aligns with REPO guidance. • Tool Usage: Manage all requirements, collaborative life cycle manage- ment functions, and trace relationships using a REPO supported tool conjunction with a REPO deﬁned template and usage model. • Release Allocation: Prioritize requirement artifacts and allocate them against releases, sprints, and development increments. • Monitor RE Execution: Monitor execution of the RE process against plans that deﬁne and control development activities and take appropri- ate corrective action when necessary. This includes responding to all feedback from REPO reviews. • Analyze Requirements: Utilize modeling, rules, visualization, and other REPO supported techniques to elaborate and decompose to a level that can be understood by the business and built against by the development team. Reusable Program Level Requirements must assessed to ensure that Section
, Security, Privacy, Operational, Custodial Financial, IPv

, etc., are incorporated into the system and development. • Visualization: Programs, projects, or releases with a user interface will leverage visualization to specify user interface requirements, screen ﬂow, and design. The visualization supports detailed user interface quirements.
2.110 Requirements Engineering
Traceability: Create and maintain requirement trace relationships that results in an integrated set of requirements, work products, and compo

nents. Trace relationships will be established and maintained in a REPO supported repository in adherence to that repository’s REPO standard. Validation: Involve stakeholder(s) in validating the RE artifacts through

out the life cycle to make sure the user’s needs are met. Stakeholder(s) should also be involved in validation activities, such as the Customer Technical Review or End of Sprint Checkpoint Review. Veriﬁcation: Engage in Peer Reviews of RE work products throughout development to identify defects early. Establish trace relationships to test cases to verify that the requirements have been met. Change Management: Incorporate change management into the devel
opment process through ongoing validation and iterations. Leverage requirements
related measures as appropriate to monitor and control progress against the project plans and identify scope creep. Apply ap
propriate change management processes when the degree of change exceeds the deﬁned scope of the effort. Conﬁguration Management: Place RE artifacts under conﬁguration man
agement levels of control in accordance with IRS CM policies, directives, processes, and procedures and in support of the reporting standards established within the ELC Data Item Descriptions.

Management: Place RE artifacts under conﬁguration levels of control in accordance with IRS CM policies, processes, and procedures and in support of the reporting established within the ELC Data Item Descriptions.
